fields.descriptive_line: Dye-line print of utility furniture made during 1941-1953
fields.physical_description: Dye-line print for a sideboard in the Utility furniture series.  The design is on a very large sheet of cream-coloured paper which is folded into eight.
fields.title: Board of Trade Utility Furniture; Sideboard
fields.location: Prints & Drawings Study Room, level C, case 3H, shelf 21
fields.marks:
'<u> GENERAL SPECIFICATION</u> / <u>MATERIALS TO BE ALLOCATED BY THE BOARD OF / TRADE  TO INDIVIDUAL MANUFACTURERS. /  ALL TIMBER TO BE SEASONED TO A MOISTURE CONTENT OF / BETWEEN 12% AND 14% AND SELECTED, SO FAR AS IS / POSSIBLE, FREE FROM DEFECTS. / DUE REGARD WILL BE PAID TO THE SELECTION OF THE / VARIOUS PARTS OF EACH PIECE OF / FURNITURE SO AS / TO ENSURE EVENLY MATCHED SURFACES. / SOLID TIMBERS AND VENEERS (WHERE SPECIFIED) / WHOLELY OR PARTLY POLISHED WILL BE OF EXTERIOR / GRADES, ALL OTHER PARTS TO BE OF INTERIOR QUALITY. /  ALL EXTERIOR SURFACES TO BE POLISHED, WILL BE  /  SANDPAPERED TO SECURE A SMOOTH FINISH. OUTSIDE / BACKS  AND INSIDES OF CUPBOARDS AND DRAWERS /TO BE SANDPAPERED SMOOTH. / ALL PARTS, PARTICULARLY JOINTS, TO BE CAREFULLY / AND ACCURATELY MACHINED, WELL FITTED AND / WHERE JOINED TO BE GLUED ON BOTH SURFACES / AND CRAMPED INTO POSITION / ALL ARRISES TO BE REMOVED.' </u>
 '<u> STAMPING</u> / <u>CORRECT SIZE OF STAMP / EACH ARTICLE TO BE STAMPED SO AS TO GIVE A PERMANENT / AND EASILY LEGIBLE IMPRESSION OF THE STAMP, INCLUDING / THE DESIGNATION NUMBER OF THE SIZE AND IN THE / POSITION SHOWN ON THE DRAWING. / DESIGNATION NO.'</u> /
 'CC41'
 '<u> FINISH: </> <u> ALL VISIBLE EXTERIOR SURFACES TO BE FINISHED / TO MATCH COLOUR BOARDS PROVIDED BY THE / BOARD OF TRADE., ALL OTHER EXTERIOR PARTS / TO BE STAINED TO MATCH. / DUE REGARD MUST BE PAID TO THE MATCHING OF / ALL VISIBLE SURFACES BOTH FOR COLOURS AND FINISH. / INSIDES OF ALL CARCASES , CUPBOARDS OR / DRAWERS TO BE LEFT CLEAN AND " IN THE WHITE". / </u>

fields.location: Prints & Drawings Study Room, level C

fields.name: Prints & Drawings Study Room, level C

fields.bibliography:
Denney, Matthew. Utility furniture and the myth of Utility 1943-1948. <u> In:</u> Judy Attfield, ed. <u> Utility reassessed: the role of ethics in the practice of design.</u> Manchester: Manchester University Press, 1999. pp.110-124. ISBN 0749052777
Leslie, Fiona. <u> Designs for 20th-century Iinteriors.</u> London: Victoria and Albert Museum, 2000. ISBN 1851773223.
fields.history_note:
'With the outbreak of the Second World war in 1939, nearly all design and manufacture in Britain went towards the war effort. After two years, Britain experienced problems with materials supply, particularly wood from the USA.  In 1941 the Government Board of Trade set up the Utility Furniture Scheme as a means of rationing production and consumption of furniture.  The board introduced specifications for controlling the dimensions and materials of pieces of furniture for all over the home: from chairs, kitchen cupboards and wardrobes to babies' play-pens.  The resulting furniture was straight edged, plain and unembellished, in which form very much followed function and construction.  The restrictions went on until 1953, and although Utility furniture furnished many middle-and lower-class homes, it was seen as an austere necessity during the war, and was soon therefore rejected after the restrictions were lifted.'
Fiona Leslie <u>Designs for 20th-century Interiors</u>  London: Victoria and Albert Museum, 2000, p.18.
fields.production_note: The date '10.3.47' printed in the column marked 'DATE'  is situated under '1st' in the column marked 'ISSUE' on the design.  The date '27.1.48' printed in the column marked 'DATE' is situated under '2nd' in the column marked 'ISSUE'.  Presumably there were two issues of this design at these particular dates.
